Award.AwardTitle: The Agrarian Origins of the Economic Growth of Nations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is designed to increase the rates of economic growth in poor nations and reduce levels of global poverty by using historical evidence to document the strategies of growth that were actually used by successful economic developers in earlier historical periods. Most successful developers, notably the U.S., Canada, Australia, Switzerland, France and Scandinavia, achieved their success on the basis of robust agriculture. A critical component of robust agriculture is improving product quality but, to date, quality has been measured through the volume or quantity of agricultural goods exported by any given nation.

We examine the agrarian path to growth by statistical analysis of economic development in the nations of the world 1870-1950. We include a new measure of excellence in agriculture, approval ratings of a nation's products by experts on food such as gourmets and home economists. We use a content analysis of shoppers' guides and cookbooks in five nations (United States, United Kingdom, France, Germany, and Italy) to obtain statistical indicators of whether nations are viewed as having superior or inferior products. We then correlate these excellence measures with both agricultural trade patterns and economic growth. Agricultural excellence is in turn correlated with other measures of social structure such as land tenure patterns and education levels. The overall goal of the project is to assess the role that agricultural product quality had in promoting economic growth in advanced nations with the hope of helping other nations develop successful institutions for converting their own agricultural sectors into engines for long-term, sustainable growth.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project tested the role of agriculture in producing the wealth of the currently industrialized nations such as the U.S. and the degree to which excellence in agricultural products was the secret of economic growth. The initial hypothesis was disconfirmed but a number of other useful causes of economic growth were identified.

The most surprising finding was the existence of a highly egalitarian path to successful economic development. Norwegian economic history is typically ignroed because the case seems arcane and obscure. However, the Norwegian record even in the nineteenth century contains relevant lessons for contemporary American growth.

Norway grew on the basis of fishing. It had no natural resources, little population, and few manufacturing skills. However, its fishing was very egalitarian. Because of unusually rich stocks of fish very close to the shore, people with very small simple boats could catch and sell large amounts of fish. Fishermen were the ultimate small business. Their boats were often no more than four people.

Yet this expansion of small business put income into the hands of everyday people. They bought simple consumer goods, such as food and clothing. (Norway is cold. Much of the new business went to woolen socks and long underwear.) This simple expansion of consumer products was enough to turn Norway into a modern industrialized economy.

They got rich without exploiting any neighbors, without engaging in any wars, and without having to squeeze or exploit workers. 

Norway represents an unusual case of a successful egalitarian development that produced real wealth. Underdeveloped nations with comparable access to simple agricultural goods may be able to replicate Norway's success without expensive capital investment, without expensive investment in education and without the social disruptions that are associated with more traditional strategies for producing economic growth.

The study also discovered the operating principles behind successful economic growth in the United States, Canada and Denmark. Denmark grew from egalitarian farmer's cooperatives producing technological excellence notably in dairy. Initially, we had hypothesized that the Denmark model would generalize to the United States and Canada. This turned out not to be the case and distinctive North American models had to be found.

We tested the Danish model by seeing if countries with excellence in agricultural manufacture were more likely to become sucessful agricultural exporters. We coded up over fifty cookbooks from Britain, the United States, France and Italy to assess what countries produced better foodstuffs according to well known established gourmets. To our dismay, we found that the food writers could not agree with each other as to whose food was best. Worse, when they did agree, the nations with highly rated food did not become successful agricultural exports - and their economies did not become rich on the basis of their great product.

In contrast, we found that the secret of economically developing a nation through agriculture is quantity rather than quality. The United States and Canada simply shipped out vast amounts of cotton, wheat and dairy products. They flooded the markets of their competitors - and this is what allowed the American South, the American Midwest and Canada to grow.

We looked at a large number of alternative explanations of what allowed the US and Canada to "go big". We did so by comparing the US and Canada with less successful countries. Most of the other explanations for North American success (education, managerial systems, capital markets, good institutions) implicitly imply that the US and Canada would be more productive than their rivals. This turned out to simply not be true. The United States and Canada were often less productive than their less developed rivals who made better use of the limited resources they had.

The great American advantage was land - lots of land. The great Pioneer move Westward, and the Great American Frontier were absolutely essential to producing a Great American Capitalism. In the Nineteenth Century, land was wealth. We had more of it than did our competitors. So they may have put great effort into squeezing the most out of the limited land they had. The United States and Canada could simply put their large territories to work - and become the largest and most reliable suppliers of cotton, wheat and dairy products globally.

The lesson from this is that land matters and frontier development matters. Under current conditions, there is a need to worry about sustainability and environmental concerns. However global poverty will not disappear unless land is put to work. Land needs to be incorporated equitably and sustainably. But it needs to be incorporated - and the world will need to keep expanding. More land means more wealth.
